ST. JOHN'S GAME MAY COME OFF

REUNION DAY DOWN THE BAY

REVIEW OF LACROSSE SEASON

MUCH FOOTBALL ACTIVITY

Possibility of It Being Played Tuesday
or Wednesday of This Week at
Homewood or Annapolis.

Strawberries, Girls, Lunches, Ice Cream,
Dancing, Old Friends and Other

Hopkins may play St. John's in
baseball either Tuesday or Wednesday of this week. Manager C. L.
Getz had a talk with Manager
Buckley of St. John's in regard
to the matter and Tuesday was the
only date that St. John's would be
able to play Hopkins this week, as
the soldier boys have games scheduled for both Wednesday and Saturday and could not play on Thursday or Friday. Dr. Abercrombie
would not sanction the ,game for
Homewood on Tuesday, though, as
a last resort, he will permit the
game to be played at Annapolis on
Tuesday.
As an alternative to playing the
game at Annapolis, Manager Getz
is trying to arrange for the game
between St. John's and Pennsylvania Military Academy, which was
to have been played on Wednesday,
to be played Tuesday. In case this
can be done St. John's will play
Hopkins on Wednesday at Homewood at 4 P. M.
All the Hopkins players are extremely anxious for the -game to
come off, and they expect to repeat
the victories of the past two years
when Hopkins has played St.
John's. Hopkins is' now at its best
in baseball, as the eleven - inning
shut-out victory over Navy a week
ago shows. Captain Pieper showed
rare form in the box against the
Middies and he can be depended
upon to pitch winning ball if the
game with St. John's is played.

Forgetful of Dean's essays, not
yet written, of final examinations,
scarcely two weeks off, the members of the various sub-committees
which have charge of the Senior
Week festivities are giving up their
entire time arranging the details of
the various events planned to celebrate thern graduation of the Class
of 1913. While Donoho busies himself persuading Mr. Fisher to supply the soul-inspiring music for the
senior prom, Richardson is off
dickering with some steamship agent
for the use of a boat for a trip
down the bay. While Meekins prepares a menu for the class supper
at Thompson's, Rusk is hiring costumes for the great 1913 class play.
The plans for the boat ride have
been completed as far as Mr. Richardson can complete them. He has
provided the boat, the strawberries,
the ice cream and the dancing.
Your old friends will come of their
own accord. You must arrange
with the girl to come, and persuade
her to bring lunch for two.Mr.
Richardson har8ecured the Sfeainer "Annapolis" for the trip. It will
leave Baltimore at i o'clock on Friday, June 6, and return to Baltimore by 10.45 P. M. A stop of
an hour and a half will be made
at Annapolis, so that those who
wish to visit the Naval Academy
on the final day of June Week may
do so. The total cost for each person will be one dollar.
A special feature of the trip will
be a monster Hopkins reunion reception, which will be held on board
the "Annapolis" shortly after leaving Baltimore. All alumni, whether
of a year of thirty years standing,
are urged to attend. The men who
did not go last year will do so this
year, if they know what is good for
them. Those who went last year
will go again this year, as now they
do know what is good for them. If
you are a, Hopkins alumni, you
should be glad to go with your old
bunch once in a while. If you are
not glad, we are sorry, and you
should be.

Once again, and for the sixteenth
time, has the Johns Hopkins lacrosse team brought home the championship banner of the Southern
Intercollegiate Lacrosse League, to
soon hang in the Trophy Room.
As. has been the case in many previous years, not only the Southern
Intercollegiate championship was
won, but also the intercollegiate
championship of the United States.
The team played eight games, of
which it lost but one—to Carlisle;
tied one—with Navy; and won six—
Alumni, Cornell, Harvard, Stevens,
Lehigh, and Swarthmore. A summary of the scores:
March 29—Hopkins,4; Alumni,2.
April 5—Hopkins 4, Cornell 2.
April 10—Hopkins 4, Navy 4.
.April I2—Hopkins II, Stevens, 0.
April 19—Hopkins 6, Harvard 3.
April 26—Hopkins 6, Lehigh 2.
May 3—Hopkins 2, Carlisle 4.
May 10—Hopkins 7, Swarthmore
4.
Total Goals—Hopkins 45, opponents 21.
--Johnny Knipp scored the greatest
number of goals, 12 in all, during
the season. He also holds the record for goals in a single game, which
is three, made against Stevens and
Harvard. Frankie La Motte comes
second with eight goals scored;
Troxell and Hollyday have five
apiece; Hulburt and Huck four
each; Tappan and Beatty, two each;
Gillet, Leibensperger and Ellicott
each shot one.
Altogether, nineteen men played
in the games this year, of whom ten
played in every game. They are:
Sears, Huck, Leibensperger, Hollyday, Beatty, Tappan,La Motte, Hulburt and Knipp. The others are:
Marshall and Gillet, 7; Ellicott, 7;
Sutton, 6; Troxell, 5; Everton, 3;
Hasson, 3; Niles, 2; Price, i ; Richardson, 1.
The rate at which goals were shot
has been calculated. The season consisted of 465 minutes (seven hours
and 45 minutes playing time). This
gives an average interval between
goals for Hopkins of 11.5 minutes
and for their opponents 22.7 minutes. This clipped nearly seven minutes off of last year's record, which
was seventeen minutes as an average.
Every man on the team ought to
be congratulated on the work he
has done during the season, and also
the coaches who really make the
Johns Hopkins lacrosse team —
Coach Wolfe, W. Schmeisser, Hulburt, Lowndes, Clark and Dr. Abercrombie—these are the men who

been advisory coach at Annapolis.

and played 'varsity end. After

Dr. Greene, of the English literature department. was suddenly
called out of the city last Wednesday
morning, and his classes were given
a holiday on Wednesday and Thursday. Dr. Greene returned in time to
resume his work on Friday.

TRACK NEWS OF THE FUTURE

TENNIS TOURNAMENT BEGINS

Championships on May 24 The Entire
Squad Entered—Four Men to
Go to Cambridge.

Thirty-four Men Entered Singles—Twelve
Teams for Doubles—Huck and
Du Bray May Win.

The disbarment of .Eller, captain
of the Georgetown track team, from
future events held at Homewood on
account of unspeakable conduct at
the intercollegiates, was the cause
of the cancellation of the dual meet
between Georgetown and the University, scheduled for last Saturday.
This action of the Homewood Committee in the matter was upheld by
the A. A. U. authorities, and this
man cannot mar the championship
on May 24.
This meet will bring together at
Homewood the best men in Baltimore, Washinkton and the vicinity.
The entries include such athletes as
Elphinstone, Geller, Everett, Prem
Johnston, Brockman, Brown and
McDonogh, all \veil known athletic
club members of Baltimore. Hopkins has entered the entire squad,
totaling thirty-two men. The stars
who have beaten all corners in the
recent meets of the 'Varsity team
will have an opportunity to repeat
against non-college athletes. Hopkins ought to win the meet with the
team trained up to the top • notch.
The met will be the last for all save
those who go to the intercollegiates

Play in the singles in the annual
tennis tournament began last Wednesday, and, at the present time, is
fairly complete. The doubles and
consolation singles will start the
earlier part of this week. Thirtyfour men entered for the singles,
while there will be twelve teams in
the doubles.
From present indications' it appears as if Du Bray should repeat
his success of last year and win
the singles. Huck is picked by
many to win the lower half and to
meet Du Bray in the finals. Gillet,
whom Du Bray defeated in the first
round, has a splendid chance of
capturing the prize in the consolation singles.

Editor for this issue, Alexander
K. Barton, '14.
Lacrosse Championship.

Captain Huck, in his review of
the lacrosse season, has covered the
ground thoroughly. Nor, indeed,
could anything THE Ews-LETTER
might say of the winning of the
lacrosse championship, equal the
praise and commendation of the entire student body. But such a record as the lacrosse team has made
this year deserves especial mention.
To Coaches Wolfe and Schmeisser and their associates, to whose
untiring efforts the success of the
team is largely due, THE NEwsLETTER proffers its most hearty congratulations. Both team and coaches
are deserving of the highest praise,
nor could the championship banner
have been brought home without the
phenomenal team work of each.
In another section of the paper
may be found an article entitled:
"Why not be a Librarian." THE
N E \vs-LETTER publishes this, as it
has published other articles this
year, in the hope of answering the
troublesome question : -What shall
T do when I get out of college ?"
Anyone who is interested, by applying to the editor, may obtain a list
of library schools.
It is fitting to suggest in this connection, the establisriment of a students bureau of self-help. A student who wishes to find work in
the college year or even in the summer time has considerable difficulty
in doing so.
We recommend the question of a
students' bureau to the attention of
the Student Council.
You cannot push anyone up a ladder unless he is willing to climb a
little himself.—Androw Carnegie.

Throw Out the Life Line!

• We were going to print the first
nineteen verses of the old song
whose chorus begins like the label
to this medicine, and would have
printed the music too, but for the
fear that all our subscribers might
fall in love with the tune. And so
we are going to administer the
medicine without music. The medicine is the same old "dope." It is
your duty, is necessary to show
your college spirit, your loyalty to
your alma mater; it is necessary to
save the honor of the school; you
will never regret it; it will be the
best ever, etc., ad infinitum, ad
nauseum, ad delirium.
But, say you, what means all this •
tommy-rot ? Have you forgotten
that the time has come for us to
urge, implore, beg, beseech and,
finally, ask you to support the
seniors in all their glorious, neverto-be-forgotten celebrations? If you
have forgotten, let us remind you.
On Thursday, June 5, at 8.30 P. M.,
the senior prom will take .place.
(For reasons why you should come,
see first paragraph.) The price is
$2.50, and there is no reason why
you should not give your support
to the seniors' project. On Friday,
June 6, at 3 P. M., there will be
the senior boat ride. (For reasons
why you should go, see first paragraph.) No one should miss this
ride. It has received THE NEwsLETTER'S endorsement, and this
should induce everyone to go.
While the seniors are not promising
a supper on board,. there will be
(lancing and refreshments. It is
also hinted that if you can say
opthalmoscopiaticrhomanticusprezygapophoses* in one breath, you can
get two blocks of ice cream. On
Saturday, June 7, the seniors will
have a gala day at Homewood, and
on Monday, June 9, the senior
class-day exercises will be held.
The senior class is not large enough
to make itpossible for them tofinance
all these excellent plans without the
help of many from the other classes.
When it comes your turn to graduate wou will appreciate this.
N. B.—Not written by a senior.

Interfraternity Meeting.

On Wednesday last was held
another regular meeting of the
Interfraternity Board. Two questions took up most of the time of
the meeting. After the question of
alumni rushing had been taken up,
and discussed at length, it was
finally laid on the table. Then came
up discussion over the nature of the
judicial body. It was moved that
the Board of Referees merely have
veto power. The next regular meeting will be on Wednesday, May 21.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 19, 1913.

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG

SOPHOMORE - FRESHMAN GAMES

SEEN AT THE HOPKINS "MOVIES"

CHEMISTS WIN AT BASEBALL

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

Second-Year Men Will Have Hard Tussle
With "Freshies"— Lacrosse
and Baseball Games.

Track and Lacrosse Men Become Film
Favorites—Intercollegiates and
Carlisle Game.

Smell -Makers and Historians Have
Match—Pitching of Pratt—Wight
and Russell Good.

The annual sophomore-freshman
lacrosse and baseball games will be
played this week. The lacrosse
game will come off today, while the
ball game willbe staged on Wednesday.
The lacrosse game should be very
close, as there are several men from
the 'Varsity squad on each team.
The attack of the 1915 Class is quite
strong with Troxell, La M otte,
Branham and Voshell; but their defense is wofully weak. On the
other hand, the freshman team is
exceedingly well balanced.
Voshell is captain and manager of
the sophomores, while Knipp and
Primrose are in charge of the freshman team.
The first year men should win the
ball game. They will have Bagley—
who will captain the team—McDowell, Smith, Copes and Wood of
the 'Varsity squad. These, together
with Richardson and Tinges,the battery of last year's Jefferson School
team, form the nucleus of a very
strong team. The sophomores, on
the other hand, have no men out for'
the 'Varsity, and, except for Voshell
and Ford, who are good pitchers,
are more or less of an unknown
quality. On paper it looks like an
easy win for the freshmen.

On Monday and Tuesday of last
week, many Hopkins students and
followers of Hopkins athletics visited
the Wizard on Lexington street to
see a reproduction in moving pictures of some of the events in the
South Atlantic Intercollegiates and
part of the Hopkins-Carlisle lacrosse
game. "Bod" Wagner is shown
winning his heat in the hundredyard dash. McDonagh's mishap in
the two-twenty is reproduced and
seems to amuse the audience. Horrax again makes some graceful
turns, ending with a hurling of the
discus. Uhler wins his heat in the
half-mile over again. In addition to
this, there is high jumping and broad
jumping. To conclude the track
performances, Catlin, the captain of
the Hopkins team, is seen walking
across the field with a hopeful, yet
modest, smile upon his face.
Part of the lacrosse game with
the Carlisle- Indians is shown. The
greatest interest is attached to Sears,
who is seen, muscles apparently
tense, ready to pick up any dangerous pass made towards the goal.

The much - discussed baseball
game between the graduate stu-+
dents of the chemical and historical-political departments was played
on Thursday last at Homewood.
The Chemists won by the score of
to 5. While the game could
hardly be called an exhibition of
big league play, due to the large
number of errors, it was enjoyed
thoroughly by the players and those
spectators who happened to be
present. Caldwell deserves great
credit for playing several innings
with a badly torn thumb.
The pitching of Pratt, who, at all
times, had splendid control, was the
feature of the game. Wight and
Russell also showed up well.

Outburst From an Irrepressible.
BALTIMORE,

To the Editor of

May 16.

THE NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir—The senior class has
decided to hold the annual prom on
Thursday, June 5. Although this
is supposed to be a senior dance, it
is really an affair for the whole University. It is up to all who can possibly come, to do so, in order to
make this the best dance ever held
in old McCoy Hall. There will be
melodious music, an epicurean supper, a jim-dandy floor and entrancingly beautiful girls. What could
be more ; attractive to any undergraduate than this ? The music will
be superlatively good, because Louis
Fisher himself, the leader of the best
dance orchestra in Maryland, will be
on hand. Get the prettiest girl you
know and bring her down on June 5.
If you do not do this you will regret, throughout your college career, that you missed the best senior
prom ever held at Hopkins. Everybody come! Freshmen, sophomores
and juniors, all be on hand with
your favorite cuties. FRESH MAN.
(Though the egotistical youngster
put the freshman class first', his effusion is, in parts, good.—EnrroR.)
Co-ed Heard From Once More.
\ \Y IC), 1912.

To the Editor of

THE NEwS-LErrER:

Dear Sir—I have not seen the
co-eds' column in your paper for
some time, but I am going to take
the liberty of craving space for a
very important matter. I want to
take this opportunity of recommending- to the University that, before
the summer school opens, it establish
a soda fountain in the basement of
McCoy Hall. Now don't laugh! If
you stop to consider the matter, you
will decide, I am sure, that it would
be a grand idea—a convenience to
the students, and a source of profit
to the University. How many of us
would not buy two or three nut
sundaes a day? Just think of what
the University could make. Let the
Administrgtive Committee give this
proposal serious attention.
Yours for the soda water,
CLARISSA

The Bible Class Committee met
in Levering Hall last Thursday to
discuss plans for securing better
Bible classes next year. One of the
questions discussed was whether or
not outside men should be secured,
if possible, to lead the classes, instead of student leaders. The number of the classes to be conducted
was debated, and it was decided to
give the individual student more or
less of an option of classes next
year, i. e., allowing him to enroll in
the class which suited his needs or
desires best. The Committee decided to ask Dr. Schwartz to repeat
his course which was so successful
this year.

JONES.

Last Tuesday evening something
happened that our musical diplomats
have been trying for some time to
bring about. The Glee Club of
Goucher College joined With our
own and gave a concert. It was
quite an impromptu affair. The concert was given at Reid Memorial
Guild Hall, on East Madison street,
for charity. After the concert, the
two clubs were rewarded with refreshments and an informal dance
followed. Those from Hopkins who
were present were: Messrs. Lloyd,
Lynch, C. I. Uhler, Weber, Wagner,
Melamet, Deei s, Spieker, Marston,
Gillet,'Fulton nd Spencer.

EXCLUSIVE
IDEAS

Actual work has been begun on
the buildings at Homewood. The
ground plans for Gilman Hall have
been completed; the cellars are dug,
the foundations laid, and the concrete work is being pushed rapidly
forward. The first brick was laid a
week ago. The contract calls for
the completion of the hall by the
first of June, 1914, and this year's
junior class can, therefore, look forward to some sort of festivities at
Homewood before they graduate.
The foundations for the chemical,
physical, geological and biological
laboratories are being dug, and the
lower quadrangle has been laid out.
Work on these buildings will be begun as soon as possible. Plans are
being hurried for the group of
technological buildings, and it is expected that actual work will be begun on them by next fall.

Dr. Wood at Atlantic City.

Dr. Robert W. Wood, professor
of experimental physics, who has
been ill at his home two weeks With
the mumps, will spend a few days
at Atlantic City before resuming his

Possibility of It Being Played Tuesday
or Wednesday of This Week at
Homewood or Annapolis.

Strawberries, Girls, Lunches, Ice Cream,
Dancing, Old Friends and Other

at Club.

Hopkins may play St. John's in
baseball either Tuesday or Wednesday of this week. Manager C. L.
Getz had a talk with Manager
Buckley of St. John's in regard
to the matter and Tuesday was the
only date that St. John's would be
able to play Hopkins this week, as
the soldier boys have games scheduled for both Wednesday and Saturday and could not play on Thursday or Friday. Dr. Abercrombie
would not sanction the ,game for
Homewood on Tuesday, though, as
a last resort, he will permit the
game to be played at Annapolis on
Tuesday.
As an alternative to playing the
game at Annapolis, Manager Getz
is trying to arrange for the game
between St. John's and Pennsylvania Military Academy, which was
to have been played on Wednesday,
to be played Tuesday. In case this
can be done St. John's will play
Hopkins on Wednesday at Homewood at 4 P. M.
All the Hopkins players are extremely anxious for the -game to
come off, and they expect to repeat
the victories of the past two years
when Hopkins has played St.
John's. Hopkins is' now at its best
in baseball, as the eleven - inning
shut-out victory over Navy a week
ago shows. Captain Pieper showed
rare form in the box against the
Middies and he can be depended
upon to pitch winning ball if the
game with St. John's is played.

Forgetful of Dean's essays, not
yet written, of final examinations,
scarcely two weeks off, the members of the various sub-committees
which have charge of the Senior
Week festivities are giving up their
entire time arranging the details of
the various events planned to celebrate thern graduation of the Class
of 1913. While Donoho busies himself persuading Mr. Fisher to supply the soul-inspiring music for the
senior prom, Richardson is off
dickering with some steamship agent
for the use of a boat for a trip
down the bay. While Meekins prepares a menu for the class supper
at Thompson's, Rusk is hiring costumes for the great 1913 class play.
The plans for the boat ride have
been completed as far as Mr. Richardson can complete them. He has
provided the boat, the strawberries,
the ice cream and the dancing.
Your old friends will come of their
own accord. You must arrange
with the girl to come, and persuade
her to bring lunch for two.Mr.
Richardson har8ecured the Sfeainer "Annapolis" for the trip. It will
leave Baltimore at i o'clock on Friday, June 6, and return to Baltimore by 10.45 P. M. A stop of
an hour and a half will be made
at Annapolis, so that those who
wish to visit the Naval Academy
on the final day of June Week may
do so. The total cost for each person will be one dollar.
A special feature of the trip will
be a monster Hopkins reunion reception, which will be held on board
the "Annapolis" shortly after leaving Baltimore. All alumni, whether
of a year of thirty years standing,
are urged to attend. The men who
did not go last year will do so this
year, if they know what is good for
them. Those who went last year
will go again this year, as now they
do know what is good for them. If
you are a, Hopkins alumni, you
should be glad to go with your old
bunch once in a while. If you are
not glad, we are sorry, and you
should be.

Once again, and for the sixteenth
time, has the Johns Hopkins lacrosse team brought home the championship banner of the Southern
Intercollegiate Lacrosse League, to
soon hang in the Trophy Room.
As. has been the case in many previous years, not only the Southern
Intercollegiate championship was
won, but also the intercollegiate
championship of the United States.
The team played eight games, of
which it lost but one—to Carlisle;
tied one—with Navy; and won six—
Alumni, Cornell, Harvard, Stevens,
Lehigh, and Swarthmore. A summary of the scores:
March 29—Hopkins,4; Alumni,2.
April 5—Hopkins 4, Cornell 2.
April 10—Hopkins 4, Navy 4.
.April I2—Hopkins II, Stevens, 0.
April 19—Hopkins 6, Harvard 3.
April 26—Hopkins 6, Lehigh 2.
May 3—Hopkins 2, Carlisle 4.
May 10—Hopkins 7, Swarthmore
4.
Total Goals—Hopkins 45, opponents 21.
--Johnny Knipp scored the greatest
number of goals, 12 in all, during
the season. He also holds the record for goals in a single game, which
is three, made against Stevens and
Harvard. Frankie La Motte comes
second with eight goals scored;
Troxell and Hollyday have five
apiece; Hulburt and Huck four
each; Tappan and Beatty, two each;
Gillet, Leibensperger and Ellicott
each shot one.
Altogether, nineteen men played
in the games this year, of whom ten
played in every game. They are:
Sears, Huck, Leibensperger, Hollyday, Beatty, Tappan,La Motte, Hulburt and Knipp. The others are:
Marshall and Gillet, 7; Ellicott, 7;
Sutton, 6; Troxell, 5; Everton, 3;
Hasson, 3; Niles, 2; Price, i ; Richardson, 1.
The rate at which goals were shot
has been calculated. The season consisted of 465 minutes (seven hours
and 45 minutes playing time). This
gives an average interval between
goals for Hopkins of 11.5 minutes
and for their opponents 22.7 minutes. This clipped nearly seven minutes off of last year's record, which
was seventeen minutes as an average.
Every man on the team ought to
be congratulated on the work he
has done during the season, and also
the coaches who really make the
Johns Hopkins lacrosse team —
Coach Wolfe, W. Schmeisser, Hulburt, Lowndes, Clark and Dr. Abercrombie—these are the men who

The disbarment of .Eller, captain
of the Georgetown track team, from
future events held at Homewood on
account of unspeakable conduct at
the intercollegiates, was the cause
of the cancellation of the dual meet
between Georgetown and the University, scheduled for last Saturday.
This action of the Homewood Committee in the matter was upheld by
the A. A. U. authorities, and this
man cannot mar the championship
on May 24.
This meet will bring together at
Homewood the best men in Baltimore, Washinkton and the vicinity.
The entries include such athletes as
Elphinstone, Geller, Everett, Prem
Johnston, Brockman, Brown and
McDonogh, all \veil known athletic
club members of Baltimore. Hopkins has entered the entire squad,
totaling thirty-two men. The stars
who have beaten all corners in the
recent meets of the 'Varsity team
will have an opportunity to repeat
against non-college athletes. Hopkins ought to win the meet with the
team trained up to the top • notch.
The met will be the last for all save
those who go to the intercollegiates

Play in the singles in the annual
tennis tournament began last Wednesday, and, at the present time, is
fairly complete. The doubles and
consolation singles will start the
earlier part of this week. Thirtyfour men entered for the singles,
while there will be twelve teams in
the doubles.
From present indications' it appears as if Du Bray should repeat
his success of last year and win
the singles. Huck is picked by
many to win the lower half and to
meet Du Bray in the finals. Gillet,
whom Du Bray defeated in the first
round, has a splendid chance of
capturing the prize in the consolation singles.

Interfraternity Meeting.

On Wednesday last was held
another regular meeting of the
Interfraternity Board. Two questions took up most of the time of
the meeting. After the question of
alumni rushing had been taken up,
and discussed at length, it was
finally laid on the table. Then came
up discussion over the nature of the
judicial body. It was moved that
the Board of Referees merely have
veto power. The next regular meeting will be on Wednesday, May 21.

THE NEWS—LETTER, MAY 19, 1913.

THE NEWS-LETTER'S MAIL BAG

SOPHOMORE - FRESHMAN GAMES

SEEN AT THE HOPKINS "MOVIES"

CHEMISTS WIN AT BASEBALL

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, but Shoulder the Responsibility.

Second-Year Men Will Have Hard Tussle
With "Freshies"— Lacrosse
and Baseball Games.

Track and Lacrosse Men Become Film
Favorites—Intercollegiates and
Carlisle Game.

Smell -Makers and Historians Have
Match—Pitching of Pratt—Wight
and Russell Good.

The annual sophomore-freshman
lacrosse and baseball games will be
played this week. The lacrosse
game will come off today, while the
ball game willbe staged on Wednesday.
The lacrosse game should be very
close, as there are several men from
the 'Varsity squad on each team.
The attack of the 1915 Class is quite
strong with Troxell, La M otte,
Branham and Voshell; but their defense is wofully weak. On the
other hand, the freshman team is
exceedingly well balanced.
Voshell is captain and manager of
the sophomores, while Knipp and
Primrose are in charge of the freshman team.
The first year men should win the
ball game. They will have Bagley—
who will captain the team—McDowell, Smith, Copes and Wood of
the 'Varsity squad. These, together
with Richardson and Tinges,the battery of last year's Jefferson School
team, form the nucleus of a very
strong team. The sophomores, on
the other hand, have no men out for'
the 'Varsity, and, except for Voshell
and Ford, who are good pitchers,
are more or less of an unknown
quality. On paper it looks like an
easy win for the freshmen.

On Monday and Tuesday of last
week, many Hopkins students and
followers of Hopkins athletics visited
the Wizard on Lexington street to
see a reproduction in moving pictures of some of the events in the
South Atlantic Intercollegiates and
part of the Hopkins-Carlisle lacrosse
game. "Bod" Wagner is shown
winning his heat in the hundredyard dash. McDonagh's mishap in
the two-twenty is reproduced and
seems to amuse the audience. Horrax again makes some graceful
turns, ending with a hurling of the
discus. Uhler wins his heat in the
half-mile over again. In addition to
this, there is high jumping and broad
jumping. To conclude the track
performances, Catlin, the captain of
the Hopkins team, is seen walking
across the field with a hopeful, yet
modest, smile upon his face.
Part of the lacrosse game with
the Carlisle- Indians is shown. The
greatest interest is attached to Sears,
who is seen, muscles apparently
tense, ready to pick up any dangerous pass made towards the goal.

The much - discussed baseball
game between the graduate stu-+
dents of the chemical and historical-political departments was played
on Thursday last at Homewood.
The Chemists won by the score of
to 5. While the game could
hardly be called an exhibition of
big league play, due to the large
number of errors, it was enjoyed
thoroughly by the players and those
spectators who happened to be
present. Caldwell deserves great
credit for playing several innings
with a badly torn thumb.
The pitching of Pratt, who, at all
times, had splendid control, was the
feature of the game. Wight and
Russell also showed up well.

Outburst From an Irrepressible.
BALTIMORE,

To the Editor of

May 16.

THE NEWS-LETTER:

Dear Sir—The senior class has
decided to hold the annual prom on
Thursday, June 5. Although this
is supposed to be a senior dance, it
is really an affair for the whole University. It is up to all who can possibly come, to do so, in order to
make this the best dance ever held
in old McCoy Hall. There will be
melodious music, an epicurean supper, a jim-dandy floor and entrancingly beautiful girls. What could
be more ; attractive to any undergraduate than this ? The music will
be superlatively good, because Louis
Fisher himself, the leader of the best
dance orchestra in Maryland, will be
on hand. Get the prettiest girl you
know and bring her down on June 5.
If you do not do this you will regret, throughout your college career, that you missed the best senior
prom ever held at Hopkins. Everybody come! Freshmen, sophomores
and juniors, all be on hand with
your favorite cuties. FRESH MAN.
(Though the egotistical youngster
put the freshman class first', his effusion is, in parts, good.—EnrroR.)
Co-ed Heard From Once More.
\ \Y IC), 1912.

To the Editor of

THE NEwS-LErrER:

Dear Sir—I have not seen the
co-eds' column in your paper for
some time, but I am going to take
the liberty of craving space for a
very important matter. I want to
take this opportunity of recommending- to the University that, before
the summer school opens, it establish
a soda fountain in the basement of
McCoy Hall. Now don't laugh! If
you stop to consider the matter, you
will decide, I am sure, that it would
be a grand idea—a convenience to
the students, and a source of profit
to the University. How many of us
would not buy two or three nut
sundaes a day? Just think of what
the University could make. Let the
Administrgtive Committee give this
proposal serious attention.
Yours for the soda water,
CLARISSA

The Bible Class Committee met
in Levering Hall last Thursday to
discuss plans for securing better
Bible classes next year. One of the
questions discussed was whether or
not outside men should be secured,
if possible, to lead the classes, instead of student leaders. The number of the classes to be conducted
was debated, and it was decided to
give the individual student more or
less of an option of classes next
year, i. e., allowing him to enroll in
the class which suited his needs or
desires best. The Committee decided to ask Dr. Schwartz to repeat
his course which was so successful
this year.

JONES.

Last Tuesday evening something
happened that our musical diplomats
have been trying for some time to
bring about. The Glee Club of
Goucher College joined With our
own and gave a concert. It was
quite an impromptu affair. The concert was given at Reid Memorial
Guild Hall, on East Madison street,
for charity. After the concert, the
two clubs were rewarded with refreshments and an informal dance
followed. Those from Hopkins who
were present were: Messrs. Lloyd,
Lynch, C. I. Uhler, Weber, Wagner,
Melamet, Deei s, Spieker, Marston,
Gillet,'Fulton nd Spencer.

EXCLUSIVE
IDEAS

Actual work has been begun on
the buildings at Homewood. The
ground plans for Gilman Hall have
been completed; the cellars are dug,
the foundations laid, and the concrete work is being pushed rapidly
forward. The first brick was laid a
week ago. The contract calls for
the completion of the hall by the
first of June, 1914, and this year's
junior class can, therefore, look forward to some sort of festivities at
Homewood before they graduate.
The foundations for the chemical,
physical, geological and biological
laboratories are being dug, and the
lower quadrangle has been laid out.
Work on these buildings will be begun as soon as possible. Plans are
being hurried for the group of
technological buildings, and it is expected that actual work will be begun on them by next fall.

Dr. Robert W. Wood, professor
of experimental physics, who has
been ill at his home two weeks With
the mumps, will spend a few days
at Atlantic City before resuming his
work at the University.
Dr. Wood was first aware of his
illness after alighting from Lieutenant Towers' aeroplane when they
had made a flight over the Chesapeake Bay. He had been feeling
badly before ascending, and the trip
aggravated his mumps.
